element_texts.text: Completed
This is the cover of the journal, and thus no words have been written.
Completed

A Sketch of a Journey to the West in the Spring & Summer of 1832
By Virtulon Rich
Completed

The pleasure that one takes in running back the course of years to those once familiar scenes which have occupied a broad space in the arena of youthful exertion, seems to carry with it a lesson that should not be forgotten: that we should treasure up of the Present whatever we may wish in aftertimes to recall. And now, from the rapidity with which the ordinary modes of conveyance transport us from place to place, it becomes a matter of necessity to note down the general features of this country with a sketch of men & manners if we would even think to obtain a correct
Completed

knowledge of the same. Besides, no one ought to be so much occupied per se, as to not labour a little for the benefit of others. Scarcely an individual could be found who does not possess some friend who would listen with pleasure to the rehearsal of the incidents of his life. Knowledge is good, and even a little, better than none. So with travelling, a little is better than none; and in giving a hasty "sketch" of my brief Tour, I shall have gained in my end can I but place on paper what will bring to mind things as they actually occured, aiming at a simple delineation rather than a studied effort to make a "sketch."
Completed

At Whiting I took the stage in the shape of an old Waggon, about 4 o'ck P.M. and reached Castleton, a distance of 23 miles, about 7 o'ck. The slow pace and bad vehicle having been rendered quite supportable, in consequence of having had the company of an old Friend, who in earlier times had been my associate in our "Alma Mater." At Castleton meeting many old acquaintances, hour after hour passed away in agreeable "chat" til the hour of one was rung and we retired. At 3 A.M. I was disturbed by the rough sound of the coachman & again I took the open waggon and, the Driver cracking the impatient steeds, we were whirled away in "double quick" over the frozen ground, still growing harder.
Completed

I had two acquaintances from V.t. The situation of the school is rather pleasant - in a neat part of the city - retired from the bustle. The Building is made of brick four stories high, 3 sides inclosed by a handsome open fence, making an agreeable promenade within.
Directly back of the city on the east rises a hill of considerable eminence. Here having resorted with a friend I feasted my curiosity, by a view among the rare from its commanding position. The scenery is highly picturesque - presenting a view of the whole city - of Lansingburg on the north - of Albany on the south with the whole line of the Hudson stretching between, whose bosom seemed a thing of life, so brisk was the commerce,
Completed

the Capitol at Washington, and bears that relation in neatness to most of the "Green Mountains State," that a genteel house in Broadway does to a log cabin of Indiana. The State House stands at the head of State St. fronting to the East, on the highest ground in the city nearly, looks down State St. and commands a tolerable view of the city. The inclosure was about done for this world, but they appropriated $10,000 to build a new one. Some distance to the north stands the Renselaer School, built of reddish brown stone 3 stories high, occupying quite a large space. There is a Department of Natural History, very interesting - various species of the most beautiful marble. Profs L.G. Beck gave
Completed

The only thing that the Albanians distinguish themselves for is their fine horses & carriages - decidedly superior to any other City in the Union for this. They are too, perhaps, the most aristocratic, & the most fond of personal display. There are yet a few of the first buildings inhabitable, built in 1600 - of brick brought from Holland - Any person who is at all familiar with the Dutch character will perceive at once here, that he is in a Dutch City - hogs and dogs - are among the most numerous street walkers - great want of neatness prevails. The Legislature should at least be commended for one thing. By regular appropriations they have accumulated a great mass of books, which constitutes an extensive State Library, which contains
Completed

before the storm - nature was three weeks behind his time. As we passed Hudson City we had a fine view of the fishermen, who were scattered about in groups of a dozen in a place to the amount of $1.00 - Sunday, seeming no protection to the fish. The fishermen I think must have had rather a cold bath--mid-deep for hours. __ At 10. o'ck eve. The births settled &c having been arranged The Roll was called in the order that the entrance at the "Capts office" had been made as we came on board. The crowd was great, no one being regardless of his prospects. At my name the call cesased. Everything canchable? being taken up. Half the passengers were left to make the best of Morpheus' company. Such a dozing group are not often seen
Completed

On the following morning the first day of May I took the unclear Boat for New Brunswick. It was rather disagreeable weather wind blowing a steady breeze from the south accompanied with rain, but in all circumstances there is generally something to render our situation tolerable, even when we are surrounded with unpleasant scenes, for 'tis not necessarily the case that our thoughts should be retained to buffet the storm. The brisk breeze was to me in this instance a source of delight! The broad canvass which, square above square, towered to an imposing height, and made the noble vessels seem things of life, as they wheeled and "tacked" obidient to the helmsman's nod, called up no ordinary feelings.
Completed

of the splendid scene which evrywhere meet the eye as we cut the briny waters, passing out of the harbour. Far to the south east, when passing Gov's Island -- steering for the Raritan Riv which separates N. Jersey from Staten Island, the eye could trace the land on either side till it finally was entirely lost in the dim distance, and nought broke the broad expanse of ocean save the mountain vessels, "wafting the burthen of an honest commerce".
As we passed into the mouth of Raritan Riv. we caught an imperfect view of Newark, (NJ) around which the country is in the highest state of cultivation. The apparent change in vegetation on either side of the Riv was remarkable. Apptitsus? which two days
Completed

to a Mr. Langworthy, whose acquaintance formerly with my Father, seemed to make him readily communicative. I learned something from him which may not be unworthy to retate. He is personally connected with "Austin's Colony" in Texas. He gave it as his opinion that there could be no better place for a "single man" to make his residence -- The land his in extensive plains -- of the first quality at this time "song cheap". The farmers business being raising cattle, which he can do to any amount. -- just keep them branded & let them run at large markets at N. Orleans & Mexico. &c &c -- Well I did not stop whilst I held a long talk with this Gent. -- interesting scenes were continually passing before us. The Riv. is from 60 to 100 yds.
Completed

be called, -- there being but one street beside some few lanes. This place is known as the seat of Learning Scientific, Classical, & Theological. There are two Colleges situated a short distance from the road, made of gray granite four stories high. A very handsome green in front tastefully arranged with shade trees. From this place to Trenton the country becomes more and more interesting, gently undulating, and perhaps second to none in N. America--at least it presents that appearance to a stranger. At Trenton The Steamer was in readiness and in a few moments we were again lounging upon the settees gazing eagerly about on either side--feasting the eye on some of the finest scenery in the travellers rout. The Riv runs
Completed

consequently the houses are spacious and far between.
Jersey Shore appears as contrasted with Pennia, a cold cheerless region, much of the country in its wild state. We caught a scant view of Count Servillier's Residence (Joseph Bonaparte). The view was rendered highly romantic, being only able to get an imperfect view as we gazed far through the willows. Sicamores and various other--trees which filled up the intervening space of low marshy ground between the bank and the ridge of land on which his private dwellings are situated. At a little distance from his house is erected a splendid observatory about seventy feet high. I was told by a friend who visited his possessions that they breathed much
Completed

So regular does the land lie, as it extends back from the Riv. and so gentle is the rise, that, altho the banks, particularly on the Pa. shore, are very low, we can scarcely get a view of the soil from the boat. No upper decks to the Boats on this Riv.
After thus having feasted myself on the variegated scenery,--the richest and best cultivated soil of America, Curiosity became delighted on seeing the far famed City of Brotherly love --Greek letters-- Philadelphia where we arrived at 6 o'ck P.M.
We passed a long line of wharves well lined with vessels, before we reach the Centre part of the City. We took up lodgings at the U.S. Hotel--the best
Completed

ornamented with shade trees.
Beside this square, there is Washington full as beautiful, & several others of less note. Franklin Square is delightful. The dwelling houses are remarkably neat and of a pretty style. The mint, which they were then nearly finishing is a most splendid Building--very large wings on each side, faced with white marble.
The 2 day of May I spent in the most busy and agreeable manner possible, viewing the curiosities of this very neat and splendid City. A Friend who had long resided in the City accompanied me in my perambulations, and explained what was unintelligible to me. 
This city probably in regularity of arrangement surpasses any in the Union.
Completed

unclear it is conveyed to the city. It is the finest--most healthy water in the World.
This Hydraulick is a place of great resort for all strangers and a delightful retreat for recreation. From this place we get a beautiful view of the "far famed Schuylkill". The Country on the opposite bank looks delightful. The splendid Country seats half shade by the rare trees of the land renders the view highly romantic. 
On our return from this visit we passed through two public gardens, which are kept with great taste--as a place of retreat during a hot summer's afternoon. In one of those Gardens there is a large 'hot house' in which many exotics are growing very thriftily. Among them was orange trees well loaded
Completed

The United States Hotel at which place I stopped is decidedly the best house in any city south of N. Yk. at least, and their charges were only 2$ per diem. 
Here the English Epicurean might destroy the rare dishes for hours. The furniture was very rich, nor did our host compel his guests to "dine on dishes". There were enrolled on the "bill of fare" eighteen dishes of meat kind all different--composed of most domestic animals besides. Ducks, wild, black birds a rare and superb dish. Pheasants & Partridges &c &c. Then six kinds of desserts, wine and all the et ceteras.
Completed

Chesapeak. This distance of 16 ms we passed in 1 hour and 40 minutes. One horse to a car. The country is miserably poor across Delaware--thin gravel sand & clay land. Frenchtown is situated on Elk Riv which empties into the Chesapeak near this place. The country from New Castle to Frenchtown is almost fruitless, cold & sterile. The trees are mostly soft maple and oak. This however is not a fair specimen of the state. 
On entering the Chesapeak the eye becomes ravished with the fine scenery--soil is quite sand, Shore rather cold. Fruit trees appear very numerous.
After entering the Chesapeak our course was to the South West in which direction no object breaks the ocean view. Where
Completed

into the heart of the city. The harbour was well filled with vessels of various dimension - Brigs, Schooners & c & c
Leaving the Steamer we proceeded to Barnum's House, in the main part of the City. On entering the house we were immediately surrounded by a herd of darkies, who were each eager to secure? as many guests as possible--it was this way & that way: "what are your commands"? "Where shall I take your" "luggage" & c & c. They were very polite: when they have executed a command they would stand half bowing, wishing to go but hesitating for the shilling, which being paid you was soon relieved. However reluctant we might be to "tip over" the ?argent for evry little notice from Ebonies? good policy soon urged it, for without it, you would get
Completed

This House which claims the first place in Baltimore I thought excelled only in one thing viz - impudence of servants and their zeal in pressuring evry guest to the utmost in order to catch the coppers.
Arriving at B at 1/2 past 3 o'ck P.M. I spent the remainder of the day in visiting whatever was most calculated to interest the Stranger. First we went to Washington Monument, situated on the highest ground on the west side of the improved part of the city. This monument is 187 ft high on the top of which stands the full statue of the Great Man. The Mont is built of white marble, or rather granite, is decidedly the first work of the kind in America. Winding stairs lead from the bottom to within 25 feet of the top. We were piloted by a little boy who,
Completed

about 16 ft. more it is round, having the names of the defenders written one after another diagonally so as to cover the whole surface: on the top stands the Goddes of liberty--holding in her hand a wreath &c.
The public buildings are not particularly elegant--nothing compared with "Phila" in this respect. Private dwellings also are not very splendid - yet substantial. The house of Mr. Wirt looks pleasant to a Yankee It is a two story brick situated in the main part of the City, on the corner of a square so that a pleasant little yard, well arranged with shade trees and shrubery, is reserved.--quite a rural scene, for a city.
On the following morning the 4th inst. immediately after Breakfast we took stage for Washington City--a distance of 36 miles--thro a very
Completed

At half past two we arrived in the great Metropolis; we were wheeled up to Gadsby's, just in season for Dinner - which there was some risque of loosing now & then, - so great was the crowd of Visitors, at this time. The Young Men's National Rep. Convention being about to sit.
One gazes around with eager eyes as he approaches the seat of our national councils. The Capitol which stands on about the highest ground in the City is the first object to rivet the attention; and whilst one looks intent upon the Giant pile he pictures to himself the various characters which figure within its walls.--elated with the idea that reality will soon supply the place of imagination.
After the necessary preliminaries attendant on taking up quarters at the busy place of a city Hotel, we passed with the crowd to the
Completed

street, on which most of the business is done: the other streets running parallel with it on the north are more generally occupied for dwelling houses. As yet in many parts of the city the houses are not very contiguous--the City extends over a very large space, making a very neat and admirable appearance when viewed from the dome of the Capitol--a situation very elevated. You gaze around with intense delight! The eye wanders 'round on one of the finest prospects it ever meets. The scenery is on the whole highly picturesque. Just 2 miles to the west stands the "White Mansion", looking from this position more like the castles of some Castilian Nobleman, than any thing American. The four state departments
Completed

Oak: on the west the City with all the departs of Govt--& still further Georgtown City--by and which there is an elevated range of forest trees: to the south west the Potomac itself--a beautiful river adorned with much delightful scenery-- Seven miles from this place on the west bank we get an imperfect view of Alexandria City, beyond which the country appears in a very uncultivated state. And pretty nearly south is the Navy Yard about one mile from the Capitol. It is situated on a beautiful plain descending to the south, is kept in very neat order; is not extensive when compared with Charleston where the Dry Dock is erected--a magnificent work built of Gray Granite--from Quincy Quarry. At this place (D.C.) there are but few
Completed

There is a splendid monument also erected to an Indian Chief about ten feet high. Also one to the Father of Dewitt Clinton about 12 ft high, designed with much taste. This is of White Marble--much carved--&c
The soil throughout the district is of the poorest, mostly yellow sand.
The Present state of things at the "white house" is said to be in a miserable condition when compared with that four years ago, when Adams superintended. 
The fence which encloses the mansion is an Iron picket placed upon a granite foundation. The gates at the entrance to the house are Iron supported by stone pillars or posts. On entering these I was disgusted with the dilapidating state of things--the contrast was so great. A small inclosure within the yard between
Completed

side of the house--consequently it is much longer than it is wide. In the middle of the room equidistant from each other stands a round table the faces of which are beautiful Italian marble--There are 5 splendid looking glasses in the room--obtained by Gen. Jackson from France. They are 5 feet wide and 9 feet long, said to have cost 5.00$ a piece. - The Curtain hangings are equally splendid. I went into five other rooms--3 below & 2 above. Those below were beautifully furnished. In one, a room oval in shape, was a splendid Italian Carpet, of one entire piece, the embroidery of which corresponding with the walls. This was furnished after a design by Mrs. Munroe. &
Completed

his manner was pleasant, easy, & at the same time dignified. He is about 6 feet in height, hair dark little inclined to be gray. it is very coarse and sticks up in divers ways--his forehead is rather low--& addorned with heavy brows--
"Old Father Holmes" the Senator from Maine is an excentrick genius. His looks indicate at once his tact at sarcasm. In serious, didactic declamation, this look seemed not to escape him. I heard him take off Isaac Hill in a manner that few would like. It was after Isaac had "read" in his place a long mess as unconnected as the poles, and as void of interest as the merest pebble on the sea shore
Completed
The Gallery being supported by marble pillars of various colours.
Completed

apartments.--the massy? columns of the most beautiful marble which support the gallery are rare specimens of American marble.--being composed of pebbles and stones of evry colour. 
The muse of History in the representative Hall is beautiful.
The paintings in the Rotunda are among the first specimens of art. They are historical paintings, illustrating the deeds of the Revolutionists--the exploits of Washington, and when our Celebrated American Artist Grenough, shall have executed an equestrian statue of Washington to be placed in the Rotunda. There will be greater attraction there than can probably be found in the same space, should you search America over.
Completed

as it came up the Potomac whispered a gentleness well timing with that feeling of the heart which one naturally feels as he reflects that he is about to triad the earth where the "Great Man" sleeps.  Our Company was of the best - 3,00 Young hearts on their way to visit the ashes of the Illustrious, the immortal Washington! - Eager to catch the inspiration of Patinatism, fresh from the tomb of America's dearest - that it should come unalloyed, - and bring upon us an impression of its intrinsic worth. -  Our landing at Alexandria City - 7 miles from the Capitol, was noticed by the vessels in Port. by the floating of the "Stars & Stripes" at half mast. We spent about one hour in visiting the City, during which time a Band of Music was engaged to accompany us.
Completed

over the door on which is inscribed a verse from the Bible together with his own name.  During our March up to the place, the Band remaining upon the Boat, played a sentimental Dirge - the faint tones went out into the grove tile although they died in the distance - After gathering around the Tomb - each one found a Shade, and then listened to the farewell Address! of Gen. Washington which was read in an impressive manner by Mr. Flagg of S. Carolina; This being done, we moved in the Same order to our Boat - Not visiting the Domains as we contemplated, in Consequence of the Illness of Mr. J.A. Wathington Washington? The House, which we could but imperfectly see through the trees, which stood quite thick from the bank of the Riv. to within a few
Completed

City was to hear the "master" in Debate (Mr. Webster) He had been out of town for two weeks - but now arriving, and an important question being before them, it was expected that he would make an effort in a few days. His competition was Mr. Hayne, who had been preparing for a shot for some time. Monday (13th May) coming, brought with it the shameful deed, which will ever cast a stain upon the City in which it occured - I mean the Affair between Herd. and Mr. Arnold. This affair had its origin in the fray between Stanburry & Gov. Houston of Tenn. Herd having become inveterate against Arnold, for words which Mr. A used when debating the Houston questn and having been incited in his purpose by the encouraging language used by
Completed

-ved, - fired the ball stripping Mr A's coat and slightly bruising the skin from his elbow to his shoulder. The ball passed within a few inches of Senator Tazwell's head and lodged in the wall. Arnold nothing daunted by the fire sprung upon his adversary - splintering the bamboo over his head, leveling his foe to the pavement – then the blows, from the naked sord of the cane, fell thick up on his victim. He farther attempted to pierce him to the heart but the sord meeting a button glanced - barely missing the flesh - again his arm was raised about to give the fatal stab when some member arrested his arm. Thus was mortal blood spillt within the very precincts of the Capitol. Heard bleeding like a butchered swine made his way unmolested
Completed

Washington City May 15   Having now satisfied my curiosity as to what relates to the Metropolis, I put myself in a way to find new objects on which to satisfy my pressing zeal for novelty. At half past three o'clock P.M. May 15th I took the stage for Frederic City Maryland a distance of 47 miles. The roads were fine and we passed] on at a rapid rate. The country is uninteresting and poor -- population very sparse as a matter of course. The soil is thin, principally yellow sand  and gravel. The timber is mostly oak - quite small. As there is much travel on this road, and as the soil is so very poor, there are numerous small Cabins about as large as a New Eng'd hog stye - and to look at them one would think
Completed

ceased, and each one communed with his own thoughts, or suffered them to follow the dictates of nature, and surrender this empire to the acting principle at whose bidding alone they revive.  About 9 oclock we entered a small village where we were to give nature "a lift" by way of taking supper. Each one seemed quite willing to try the little trotting Landlord's mess altho from general appearances an empty stomach would not have murmured much had it not been presented with our Host's best. We arranged ourselves around a "scared dish" as a Yankee would say - and suffered our ivory to try its heft upon a well dried steak that would have made a french-man an imperishable hathn? apron. But not to be too particular, we paid our Bills and again entered the Coach. If indeed I had used my stomach rather ill, I had at least
Completed

Baltimore.
At this place I was obliged to remain till 12 o'c'k next day the 16th. In the mean time I promenaded almost every strut in the City, not because          I was so delighted with its appearance, but because it was my province to visit as well what was fair as that which was not so.  Frederic City is quite an important place for the interior of Maryland. - It lies upon the National Road. The Rail Road also terminating here makes it a sea port as it were. The town is regularly laid out, but the streets are quite narrow-handed? very indifferent - Many old buildings built of hews logs are yet standing in the main part of the city. The best buildings are generally small & made of brick. As the Court was
Completed

and indeed I can truly say that I was much disappointed in finding so few facilities for general information to be diffused. The Atlantic Cities and Eastern towns furnish a well timed rebuke to these selfish views of the Keepers of Public houses in the middle States.  Here the aim of the Hosts is to secure to himself a liberal bill with as little expense as possible.  About 1 o'clock P.M. I bid adieu to Frederic and again resumed my seat in the state - being well satisfied with the repose which the last twelve hours had afforded me. The weather being fine I resumed my journey with alacrity.  The Country presents a very rich appearance from this place onward to Hagerstown, which is a flourishing inland town - in perfect keeping with its kindred in this Country - the Houses crowded together with all the
Completed

on the mind, as I was fast winding my way westward - drawing comparisons perhaps between what I daily saw, and those things which I have left far behind. And there is too, a kind of speculation occupying the mental faculties, when rapid travelling crowds the memory with incidents -  On the following day we passed through a well cultivated country, & saw much picturesque scenery - sometimes ascending for a mile or two - and then making an abrupt decent this day was particularly pleasant - weather fair - a few fleeting clouds sailing through the heavens - Scenery far faimd?  Nine cheerful passengers composed our Company - This was the second day of our travelling together - One of the Company - Mr. Ritchy a Merchant of Phila had often travelled over the road in earlier times  He related many legiondary tales the scene of which we passed in our route.
Completed

and the west. A fine Spring of living water flows from this summit having two courses - the one trickling off to the Potomac - The other winding its way to the Missisippi - As we descended on the west side of the Allegany, the prospect became highly grand The fine large plantations far down in the vale, seemed mere courtyards - and the large Commodious house of the Planter, a mere youthful toy?-house. At 9 o'clock in the Eve we (being in the accomodation line) put up for the night. At 3.A.M. we again took our seats in the state - and passed through a sterile country for about twenty miles - then again the appearance grew better. At the public houses at which we called I was reminded of a "yankee story" when a peddlar failing to sell the
Completed

unclear meeting? death in a frightful shape  Nothing peculiar met our view till we reached the famous City of Pittsburgh, which was about 6 oclock P.M. on the 18th.  This city is nearly surrounded by hills  As a manufacturing Town it is in fact the Manchester of the West, This I would say is Vulcan's? own City. The tale files? of Chimneys are immense - out of which thick black Columns of smoke are continually rolling forth - I will not pretend to emmenate? the number of Foundaries, forges, nail factories, Cotton Manufactories, Glass works & the like that are continually in operation here.  There seems to be great enterprize in evry department.  One morning I took occasion to saunter out upon the Hill which skirts the town on the East, in order to obtain a full view of the Whole City - I went early - all was
Completed
transcribers note: this is a duplicate page
Completed

fires? - I marched back to town perfectly disgusted with the dirty hole.  As a business place, I think it takes the bad of any I was ever in, - all is "go ahead" The houses as a matter of course are all very black with soot, which is continually falling, so as to be continually in one's face, and the remark is proverbial, that you can never see a Lady or gent, with a clean face - The publick houses are tolerably well kept, and always thronged - Many of the private dwellings appear very substantial yet not "showy". The Episcopal Church is an elegant building - and about the only one worth remarking about - The streets are truly western i.e. very narrow - & paved with round stone. I was credibly informed that during the winter season it is not uncommon to dine by
Completed

and looking more like a farmers son just from the field, than students -  After dining at Washington we took the National Road for Wheeling Va, this road was considerably out of repair yet we were in "the Mail? & we made about 7 1/2 miles the hour - We were not entirely at our Ease as we jotted along - accidents being quite frequent - Within five miles of Wheeling we passed a splendid monument standing a few Rods from the road. This monument was erected by an independent farmer, whose residence stood a little distance beyond - in honor of Henry Clay as the Champion of domestic industry & internal improvement  The monument is about 10 feet high, is built of light granite & cost 5000$  We reached Wheeling in safety about sun set.
Completed

Wednesday eve I took the "mail line" for Zanesville - a distance of seventy four miles west upon the Nat. Road  We crossed the Ohio River by a ferry and then proceded upon one of the finest roads in the world - we re?ed? along in the stage at the rate of about 9 miles the hour, about as smoothly as upon the rail Road - night coming on we slept quite comfortably during a rainy night. About 7 o'clock we alighted at the National House in Zanesville - a Town containing above 4000, inhabitants -
Completed

A natural? face in the River at this place affords a fair supply of water-power. --yet not adequate to the wants of the place, for there are two saw mills--one cotton manufactory--one oil mill--one paper mill, all propelled by steam power; coal being abundant, it is found to be about as profitable as water power.
At this place then is one Court house, one Baptist? meeting house, one methodist, one Prebysterian, one unknown, one Roman Catholic, & one for Blacks together with a very neat Episcopal Church. There are upwards of fifty dry? goods. Here, besides numerous greasy tins--Two Book unknown, (poor apologies)
Heaving unknown an old friend residing here who "hailed" from the "green hills" as as well as myself. I spent a week
Completed

and cramed? them into a unknown, and mailed it to the front part of a saddle, with my overcoat & umbrella behind. Thus unknown about 8 o'clock A.M. I put off. The undertaking seemed rather arduous to me--unaccustomed to long rides when horseback.--I had a long road before me, but the thoughts of seeing the "west" made the prospect look cheerful--Heaving supplies myself with letters of introduction at this place from such a aquaintances as I had made during the week, I bid adieu to Lanesville & unknown off at the rate of four miles an hour. My point of destination was Cincinnati. The first town of any consequence west of Lanesville is New-ark, a distance of twenty five miles. The canal from Portsmouth on the Ohio River to unknown on The Lake, passes thro this town-- Making business here quite flourishing--the town contained a population
Completed

log cabin said "we keep a private entertainment" However as I neared the house I saw no guide board for a stranger, & concluding that I did not exactly seek "private entertainment" I continued my course. Here I will remark that it is the custom through this country for all those who can furnish a hovel for a beast, and a spare bed for a guest, to stick up a shingle upon a pole, with this rude inscription where it, "Private entertainment." Such is not unfrequently the case when their whole house affords but one room--rather "tuff" times for a New Englander at first--
For the last twenty miles before reaching Columbus--the Capital of Ohio, I passed through a country of rich soil--level as the surface of a calm ocean--with but here & there a mean cabin.
Completed

The houses are mostly made of brick, and are quite large generally -- look more substantial than those in most towns. There are about fifteen stores, well stacked-- The large Public House near the state House is said to be the best in the state--there are also three or four others, two of which are very good--The state House is a brick building square roof--steeple in the centre--two stories high--& about 50 feet square.
The state Prison lies off at the south west corner of the town--a miserable old thing. There is a very elegant brick Presbyterian meeting house on the south side of a very large Public Square--on the north there is being built a splendid stone Episcopal Church--The Court house is a poor thing. The state Library is, as yet, in its infancy, yet containing a very good assortment of books and Periodicals.
Completed

Dayton Ohio.
and neat--roads coarse gravel--side walks paved with large flat lime stone--formed of depositions of marine shells. The dwellings are large and neat. The Stage House is a very large & well kept Tavern--there are several other taverns in Town--a Court House, tolerable Presbyterian Church, and a Unitarian Church--the first I have seen in the state. There is a pretty good cotton factory here also. A few miles before reaching this town I passed a large and very beautiful "Mound"--about 300 yards around the base--& about 12 feet high, or 16, situated in the midst of an extensive plain --a beautiful young orchard is growing upon it--Small mounds are very common in this Country--so far as they have been examined -- they appear to be Indian Cemeteries--
Completed

Here for the first time since I left Lanesville I discovered some lime stone ledges. For the last fifty miles indeed I have scarcely seen a rock of any kind. 
On Saturday 1st June I reached Dayton. This is a splendid town--situated in the midst of the finest quality of lands that I have ever seen. The town is nearly surrounded by water--on the north made Riv. a small yet violent stream, on the west the Miami River--a beautiful stream usually about 20 Rods wide: on the east a "side cut" Canal--the ground on which the town stands appears to have been at an early day the bed of a River--a level?, gravel alluival. On the west there is a levè about 8 feet high to keep the water from flowing into town in high water.
The Streets are regular and very wide
Completed

Cincinnati
Dayton, I reached the great city of the woods.
The road leading in to the city on the north
is paved for upwards of two miles from the 
town, and quite the city inhabited on either
side.
The impression upon the mind made by
travelling so recently through a comparatively
wild country, and then entering this Boston
of the west, is of a peculiar kind - Turn
back but fifty years, and the Red man
pursued his game when now stands a
noble city with a population of 30,000.
Not having made the proper inquiries
before entering this city, as to the Public
House most agreeable, my sight was
my guide in selecting a place to alight.
I peddled by several till I came to one
presenting a pretty fair appearance - directly
east of the Market house and nearly at
the highest elevation of main street.
Completed

Finding a gent? here with whom I had recently become acquainted in Washington City. I was treated with great kindness by him and prolonged my stay in town two days, one of which being Sunday I went to Church. 
As a general rule, I think the Ohians are very generous to strangers, who come among them properly recommended. 
Leaving unknown on Monday I proceeded onward to Cincinnati, a distance of 57 unknown. This may be said to be the garden of Ohio--and my Road bordering the banks of the Miami rendered it very pleasant. The Canal also is mostly in sight of the Road, the whole distance from Dayton to Cincinnati. The only town of any note between the two points is Hamilton, tho being situated near a populous City it does not advance in improvement since it is 28 miles distant from Cinc'ti.
On the P.M. of the 8 day's ride from
Completed

Cincinnati
of brick, as are nearly all the houses in the city.  Well furnished in all its department, A large reading Room belonging to the Establishment, where one might find papers from all sections of the Union.  Next in importance, as a public House, is the Broad Street House - directly in front of the unknown on the South - 
Cincinnati lies in the main, on the south side of a hill descending to the South.  Main Street runs north & south through the City - all the streets running parallel or, cutting this at right angles -
The Public houses are as yet not particularly attracting many are built quite large, yet less substantial than those of our Eastern Cities - Many a Brick? Edifice is rebuilt after standing 10 years.  The Market house is a low inferior shed in the upper part of the City -
Completed

Cincinnati
It was Dennison's, - a house of immense patronage - mostly of mercantile men from the Country - yet with all its patronage it was a miserable house for a gentleman on a tour of observation, who tarries a few days to recruit? & make observations, to stop at. - Evrything must be under a lock and key or losses might occur.
I spent four days in town and I think there were about 200 each day to dine - and whenever the "alarm" was given there was a shameful rush - hungry hogs never showed off better -
By reconnecting the Grand? in Town I found several superior ones, - filled with guests of less voracious habits - Gentlemen and Ladies of tastes more refined - The Pearl Street House in the lower (South western) part of the city I think stood first - four stories high, built
Completed

Louisville to New Orleans a distance of about 2,000 miles - They are never propelled up Stream - When they arrive at N.O. they are sold for a mere trifle for wood - Another kind of boat in common use in all the western waters is the Keel. Similar to the Canal boat and carrying from 50 to 70 tons - These are pushed up the Rivers by men with poles - there being a walk on each side and about from 5 to 9 men on a side - 
During my stay in Cincinnati I found some old acquaintances, and by letters made several new ones. I was treated with much cordiality & politeness - and on being about to Start, having determined to go as far as St. Louis M.O. a distinguished member of the Bar, an eastern man, kindly furnished me with letters - Thus after a stay of four days I again started for the
Completed

Cincinnati
The new Medical College is a very pretty brick two stories -
The Commerce of this place is immense not less than half a dozen Steam boats may at all times be seen at the Wharf besides other "craft" peculiar to this River unknown  "Broad horns" (a species of flat bottom Boats from 70 to 90 feet long to 20 broad, that part which runs in the water being similar to the N. England scow boat - These "Broad horns" are generally navigated by four men - One helmsman & three "sweeps" - There is a long oar on each side from 40 to 50 feet long, and one of similar dimensions projecting from the Stern - The boat is about 8 feet deep - having a temporary Roof  These boats are capable of carrying about 900 lbs of flour - They float down the River - being? about 6 weeks in going from
Completed

At 5 oclock P.M. of the 8th June I packed off my horse again & crossed the Ohio River into Covington K.Y. upon the South bank. This is a small town, having a cotton factory & Iron works in it - It is separated from another Small Town called Newport containing a population of 500. by a small River called Licking. During this P.M. I rode 18 miles to a very good public House - large & splendid - plenty of slaves attached to the premises - The country thus far is quite pretty, being gently rolling - yet much poorer than that in Ohio. I could easily see that I was in a Slave State -: in each little town that I passed I saw the white sporting & "carousing" at the miserable "doggies" (groceries) and the blacks in the fields - male & female
On the 9th I again pursued my way alone, save my faithful horse, which
Completed

"West" Whilst however I was here I took occasion to crop over into Kentucky to see a little of the genuine character so celebrated in all the "tales of the West". There was to be a "horse Race", a favorite amusement with the Kentuckyans - 
It required no nicety of perception to see that I was among a new race - They were perhaps what are termed "Wild Kentuckyians" They were collected in a large field in the centre of which were several boothes erected calculated to suit the occasion - as they were well supplied with liquor & gaming devices. From the "Farrow Bank" down to the "Chucky lucks" In another direction, they were sporting with the Rifle
I found them a rough set, all of the roughness of the K.Y. character without any of the blandishments. The race "blew over", and I soon returned in disgust.
Completed

K.Y.
rendered my ride pleasanter than usual He told me how to travel on horseback. Feed my horse & myself sumptuously in the morning and then ride till night without stopping - or ride 10 miles before breakfast - stop an hour or more, then travel on till night - give my horse half a bushel of oats at night 0 Such is the custom of this country, and the true course.
We rode 14 miles through a tolerable country, especially for sheep - the hills being numerous, when we reached Geo. Town - a silent country town containing a population of about 800. Here the country assumes a new appearance - more level and deeper & better soil: and from this town onward to Lexington City, the country presents an enchanting appearance Land in a high state of cultivation
Completed

although it got a plenty of corn is suffered much for the want of water. The Country seems very poorly supplied and it being a "dry time" the people would not give my horse water from their wells. Nothing worthy of mention occurred this day. The country I passed through was quite hilly & well supplied with lime stone - laying over the surface of the earth in strata of about a foot in diameter - under which, the sandstone often lay.
Sunday the 10th I left my host about 7 oclock, and after breakfast with Company for the first time - He was a Native of Rhode Island, and a resident of K.Y. he was travelling on horseback his wife & child - a young lad accompanying him in a chaise. The day was fair & the company of this intelligent gent,
Completed

(Lexington)
will shaded with ornamental trees of various kinds - an anomaly in fact in the Western Country - save it be in a Yankee town.
The Insane Hospital is a large 3 story brick - standing some distance from the main part of the City in the midst of a large & beautiful plain - In another direction there is being erected a very splendid College There is also a fine Medical College at this place.
The Residence of the Great American Statesman Henry Clay, is one mile east from the court house. His situation is truly splendid - not in the gaudy dress with which the works of art decorate his mansion - but splendid with the rich profusion of nature's ornaments - The House is a two story Brick, painted led
Completed

Here and there a grove of sugar maple & beach trees - the grass being thick throughout these groves - free from all kinds of under wood - at 4 oclock I alighted at a large and commodious tavern in the heart of the city. It being Sunday the population appeared very neat - not excepting the darkies; for to judge from personal observation I should think about one fifth of the population were blacks.
The City is by no means compact not so much so even as some of the western villages - The streets are wide & regularly laid out - Main Street Runs East & West and is McAdamized The Court House stands in the centre of the City; forming a neat public Square - laid out into walks and well ornamented with shade trees and in fact the Wide walks are quite
Completed

(LEXINGTON)
colour, having a wing upon the South & North - It stands back from the Road about sixty yards: a winding is rather curved walk leading to the House, with a thick row of trees of all descriptions on either side. This circular walk makes a semi-circle between the House & the Road so that as travellers pass along the road The house is difficult to be seen. Within these two rows of trees thickly growing on each side of the foot path about 4 feet wide, lies a beautiful field of grass - On the east, without the enclosure which contains the house There is a beautiful maple grove containing about 15 acres - Looking more like the sylvan shades celebrated in Grician song, than any real one I had ever before beheld. A situation like this I thought must be relinquished with some regret to engage in the angry contest of a political campaign.
Completed

me if they had corn for my horse which by some casualty had become lame some day before. In my inquires I was directed to, one, as to another the suggestion always bring made that "they have corn for your beast." For the last few miles of my inquiries I began to think I should find a convenient place to rest my bones that night. On arriving at the noted place I saw things looked pretty fair high fences- flourishing fields of growing corn, and what was rare, two log houses making together a rather extravagant abode for one of these animals that live so far in the woods. I rode afar to the fence- called to a tolerably well clad female save she was barefoot. She came near as to my inquiries save She thought her "man" would help me" as
Completed

Stranger is that it was of little consequence to his purposes to entertain me. So I rode off cursing the office hunters. At the end of two miles as i rode up the "lane" two faithful dogs met me half way, and gave me a hearty salute. On arriving at a less cheerful appearing cabin, I made the necessary inquiries of a fiery headed middle aged woman not forgetting to throw in two words for my horse, which I had now rode 48 miles since morning- only stopping once in the time) where
